Review Title: Not For Everyone (But Excellent For Some)
Pros: - Lots of learning and growth. Plenty of opportunities if you seize them (and earn people's trust along the way) - Fast paced and dynamic culture. Pivot quickly, and implement new things at lightning speed. - Teams of highly talented people. People are highly intelligent and are comfortable with complexity. - Great leadership (esp CEO)
Cons: - Some tumult in business outlook, esp with BNPL closure of one market and multiple (and quickly successive) departures of key figures in that business - Lack of work-life balance. Tight deadlines, quick turnarounds, and intense stress to excel. Might not be for everyone's personality and/or current phase of life right now - Lack of diversity in strengths, personalities, and backgrounds. Results in certain traits being self-selecting over time, which can breed very rigid (possibly elitist) thinking over time. - Almost no formal DEI initiatives, and what is being done is mostly for B2C marketing campaigns (e.g. international women's day). Expect very little support as it's not seen as a company priority at all (literally the last thing on the list) - Some toxic personalities in middle management

Review Title: Think Twice: A Cautionary Review for Prospective Employees
Pros: Hybrid working arrangement is the only one I can think of.
Cons:
Working at ShopBack is challenging, and unfortunately not in the positive sense. The company suffers from a significant lack of planning, often setting arbitrary deadlines that seem disconnected from project realities. This approach breeds a chaotic work environment where overtime is not just common but explicitly encouraged. The expectation to work nights, weekends, and even holidays is glorified, with the CTO publicly praising such unsustainable practices.

While compensation is average, the expectation to deliver high-quality work under these conditions is unreasonable. Work-life balance is virtually non-existent, as personal time is frequently encroached upon by work demands.

There's a discernible culture that values compliance over competence, where 'yes men' are favored over those who genuinely contribute through hard work. This environment is compounded by a management style that fails to advocate for team members, often leaving them feeling unsupported and undervalued.

Pros: Depending on your role within the company, you can achieve a a happy medium in terms of work-life balance. Nonetheless, the salary offered is decent. Theres a good company culture going on at ShopBack with continuous development opportunities to grow your skills.
Cons: * While the company offers AL, Sick Leave, and company stocks to vest - the downside to some of the benefits include no company provided insurance plans. Furthermore, if you travel for your role or have to purchase misc. adhoc items, you have to front the cost upfront and wait to expense the items to be reimbursed.

Pros: Good learning environment and room for error given
Cons: Not much as an intern, just a good place to learn

Review Title: ShopBack is one of the best companies Ive worked with
Pros: 1. management shares their visions and progress towards common goals monthly via townhall, with great details, very candid. this helps everyone in the company (now we have 1000+ employees) to know and ask questions via slido 2. Bosses give a lot of freedom to employees to decide what they wanna do. it doesn't stop there, bosses are supportive in terms of giving guidance and will fight for the resources you need (of course you need to prove what you do is impactful) 3. Most people in the companies are quite willing to help each other. No question is dumb, and normally we can ask the same question again and again until we fully understand 4. People here work hard, peer pressure is healthy for most to constantly upskill themselves. a bit stressed short term, but fruitful long term 5. We also play hard. You heard of whole company annual retreat on a Yacht? or flying to Phuket, or have a whole Club (the ones with drinks and music)? ya thats ShopBack
Cons: 1. processes are still quite manual. means sometimes we need to OT to get things done, while in other more mature companies, it could have been automated 2.should have been more proactive in engaging employees what skills they wanna develop and provide trainings. currently we do have IDP, but many people dont use it

Pros: Great work environment with above average talent pool
Cons: No product innovation or product road map

Review Title: Not for everyone, but great if you are willing to hustle
Pros: Great culture and there's a very flat hierarchy, making it very easy to get things done. People are generally very willing to share/teach you new things, as long as you ask for it. Plenty of growth opportunities as the company supports cross-team transfers to help individuals learn new things. No micromanaging (at least within my team), and the bosses trusts in the team to get the work done.
Cons: Everything about the work in ShopBack is time-sensitive, so this means that work-life balance may be tough during peak periods. Culture is definitely getting more "corporate" as the company grows and there are more middle managers, which may or may not be a good thing as this means that there's more "layers" to go through to get things moving.

Pros: Many opportunities for you to learn new things, should you want to take them on. ShopBack favors those who work smart and hard, and bring impact to the company. People who just want a free ride will not be tolerated, which is good for the team as no one will be latching onto others for good performance.
Cons: Can be highly stressful if you don't know how to manage your time and prioritize properly. Also can be lack of guidance if you don't know how to be specific and seek for it. Help is wherever and whenever you might need it but you need to properly ask for it.

Review Title: Good place for growth, but requires tremendous amount of work, and self learning.
Pros: Exposure to interesting people with a wide range of experience and no hierarchy.
Cons: Difficult to find work life balance, there can be a lack of organizational structure.

Pros: Get to work from home for most days.
Cons: The level of support provided to employees by management was lacking, with insufficient efforts made to nurture their growth and development. Commission structures were poorly planned, resulting in frequent changes that often had negative impacts on earnings. The management was known for engaging in gossip, creating an environment of mistrust and backstabbing among employees. Despite claiming to understand the challenges faced by employees in dealing with client objections, management failed to provide effective solutions. Employees were expected to maintain a high standard of work and often had to perform tasks outside of their designated roles, without any corresponding increase in salary. Standard Operating Procedures were constantly changing, resulting in frequent adjustments to administrative duties. Management seemed to believe that employees should be grateful for the opportunity to work at Shopback, a company they considered prestigious, and viewed departures as ingratitude on the part of employees who chose to leave.

Pros: - Lots of opportunities to grow - Many smart and hardworking people to learn from - Encouraging environment
Cons: - Sometimes can be stressful to keep up with the pace

Review Title: Not for everyone. If you are a foreigner, don't get lured to the compensation and simple / easy interviews.
Pros: * Fast paced work on latest technology. * Genuinely friendly and helpful co-workers (with few exceptions). * Flat hierarchy. * Opportunity / exposure to modern development and deployment practices and on the job training for relevant technologies. * Tech talks, quarterly engineering improvement sprints where everyone can contribute to an idea not directly related to business. * Diversity is great.
Cons: * Frequent change of direction from PM. * Churn in development due to new / ad-hoc requests vs priority bug fixes. * Some teams have very little process around testing and deployment, it's no wonder there will be patch fixes in Production * Lot of responsibility on team leads for stability of application. So, expect tough consequences when things fail. * Inclusion is sometimes missing and may have to struggle to fit in.

Review Title: Non-existent career progression and terrible commission structure
Pros: Flexible working hours and only required to report to office once a week.
Cons: HR will lowball your base pay and promise good commissions. However after you accepted this role, you will realize the commission structure is extremely terrible and changes significantly every quarter. Furthermore, there isn't a proper progression structure for entry level BDs and management will dangle the carrot in front you to spur you to work towards a possibility of some kind of promotion and advancement which will never happen. Basically, you are just being utilized to bring in the numbers and will get disposed if you voice out any form of dissatisfaction or such. They will deem you as an employee who doesn't align with the company values and will lowkey manage you out for another replacement. Little to no employee welfare.

Review Title: Great place to learn and accelerate your career
Pros:
-Great culture, politicking is almost non-existent, people are genuinely friendly and care for your well-being

-1 year at ShopBack gives you 3 years worth of learning and experience at other companies; you will find that you've grown a lot and are ready to take on tougher challenges at a pace you didn't think likely before

-Career progression here is non-linear; if you do well enough, regardless of your age or years of experience, you will find yourself being promoted very quickly

-Retention rate is much higher compared to other tech companies, other than the new joiners, most of the people here have been around for 4-5 years (the company is only 7 years old)

-High-caliber colleagues; this is of course dependent on the team itself but most people I've interacted with are pretty smart. Says a lot about the company that for the good performers who do end up leaving, most of them end up in global tech giants like FAANG for example

-Stock value has multiplied several times in the past few years, which also explains the high retention rate and spurs people to work harder
Cons:
-Not for everyone because of how fast-paced the company is, everyone is expected to carry their own weight and then some, definitely not someplace you can chill and still expect to be an average performer

-Benefits are not great, insurance and allowances while decent are still below that of other comparable tech companies
